emergencies.title: Medical Emergency Instructions
emergencies.summary: If someone is unconscious, bleeding heavily, or having trouble breathing, act quickly.

instructions.title: Assess the Situation
details: Check the area for any dangers to yourself or the victim (like traffic, fire, or fumes).
Try to wake the person by gently tapping their shoulders and shouting, "Are you okay?"

instructions.title: Call for an Ambulance (108 or 112)
details: Tell the operator your exact location.
Describe the person's condition (e.g., "not breathing," "bleeding from the head," "chest pain").
Follow all instructions the operator gives you.

instructions.title: Provide Basic Care (If you can do so safely)
details: If not breathing: If you are trained, start CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation).
For heavy bleeding: Apply firm, direct pressure to the wound using a clean cloth or bandage.
Do NOT move a person with a suspected neck or spine injury unless they are in immediate danger.
Stay with the person and keep them calm until help arrives.

emergencies.title: Fire Emergency Instructions
emergencies.summary: Your priority is to get everyone out safely. Things can be replaced, people cannot.

instructions.title: Alert Everyone
details: Shout "FIRE!" loudly to wake up and warn everyone in the building.

instructions.title: Evacuate Immediately
details: Get out as fast as you can. Do not stop to collect personal belongings.
Stay low to the ground to avoid inhaling smoke. The cleanest air is near the floor.
Before opening a door, feel it with the back of your hand. If it is hot, DO NOT open it. Find another way out.
Once you are out, stay out. Never go back inside a burning building.

instructions.title: Call the Fire Brigade (101 or 112)
details: Call for help only after you are safely outside.
Tell the operator your exact address.

instructions.title: If Trapped
details: Go to a room with a window. Close the door to keep smoke out.
Block the gap under the door with clothes or a towel.
Signal for help from the window.

emergencies.title: Natural Disaster Safety
emergencies.summary: Instructions will vary depending on the disaster (e.g., earthquake, flood, cyclone). Follow official news and alerts from authorities.

instructions.title: Find Safe Shelter
details: Earthquake: Drop to the ground, take Cover under a sturdy table, and Hold On. Stay away from windows.
Flood: Immediately move to higher ground. Do not walk or drive through floodwaters.
Cyclone/Strong Winds: Stay indoors, away from windows and doors.

instructions.title: Stay Informed
details: Listen to the radio or follow official social media channels for updates and instructions.

instructions.title: Emergency Kit
details: Keep a kit ready with water, non-perishable food, a flashlight, batteries, a first-aid kit, and important documents.

instructions.title: After the Event
details: Watch out for downed power lines, broken glass, and damaged buildings. Do not enter damaged structures.

instructions.title: Secure the Area
details: Stop your vehicle at a safe distance and turn on your hazard lights to warn other drivers.
Check for immediate dangers like fuel leaks, fire, or oncoming traffic. If it's safe, place a warning triangle.

instructions.title: Call for Help (100 for Police, 108 for Ambulance)
details: Provide the precise location of the accident.
Describe the number of vehicles and people involved and the extent of injuries.

instructions.title: Assist the Injured
details: Your safety comes first. Only approach if it is safe to do so.
Check if the victims are conscious and breathing.
Do not move an injured person unless they are in immediate danger (e.g., from fire). Moving someone can worsen neck or spinal injuries.
Offer first aid if you are trained (e.g., applying pressure to bleeding wounds).
Talk to the victims in a calm and reassuring voice until help arrives.

emergencies.title: Responding to a Violent Threat (Assault/Robbery)
emergencies.summary: Your personal safety is the single most important goal. Follow this principle: RUN, HIDE, or FIGHT.

instructions.title: RUN (Escape)
details: If there is a clear escape path, use it immediately.
Leave your belongings behind.
Do not try to be a hero. Get yourself to safety first.
Once safe, call the Police (100 or 112).

instructions.title: HIDE (If you cannot run)
details: Find a place where the attacker is less likely to find you.
Lock or barricade the door.
Silence your mobile phone completely (including vibration).
Stay quiet and out of sight.

instructions.title: FIGHT (As a last resort)
details: Only fight if your life is in immediate danger and you cannot run or hide.
Be as aggressive as possible. Commit to your actions.
Use any object as a weapon (chair, fire extinguisher, keys, pen).
Aim for vulnerable areas.

emergencies.title: Rescue Situation Instructions
emergencies.summary: If you see someone trapped, fallen, or in danger, your first step is to get professional help.

instructions.title: DO NOT put yourself in danger!
details: Assess the situation from a safe distance. Look for hazards like fire, deep water, electric wires, or unstable ground.
Many rescuers get injured or killed by rushing in without thinking. You cannot help if you also become a victim.

instructions.title: Call Emergency Services Immediately (101, 108, or 112)
details: Give them the exact location and describe the situation clearly. (e.g., "A person has fallen into a well," "A child is trapped under a collapsed wall").
Professionals have the right training and equipment to perform a safe rescue.

instructions.title: Help from a Safe Distance (If possible)
details: DO NOT enter the dangerous area.
Talk to the person. Keep them calm and let them know help is on the way.
For water rescue: Do not go in. Try the "Reach, Throw" method. Reach with a stick or branch, or throw them something that floats (a rope, a plastic bottle).
Follow any instructions given by the emergency operator.

emergencies.title: Seeking Mental Health Support
emergencies.summary: General guidance on when and how to seek help from a psychiatrist for mental health concerns. This is not a substitute for professional medical advice. If you are in immediate crisis, please contact an emergency helpline.

instructions.title: Recognize the Need for Help
details: Pay attention to persistent feelings of sadness, anxiety, hopelessness, or irritability.
Notice significant changes in sleep patterns, appetite, energy levels, or concentration.
Be aware of withdrawal from social activities or loss of interest in hobbies you once enjoyed.
If you are having thoughts of harming yourself or others, seek immediate emergency assistance.

instructions.title: Find a Qualified Professional
details: Ask your primary care doctor or general physician for a referral.
Check with your insurance provider for a list of covered mental health professionals.
Use reputable online directories from psychiatric associations or health organizations.

instructions.title: Prepare for Your First Appointment
details: Write down your key symptoms, concerns, and when they started.
Make a list of any current medications, past mental health treatments, and your family's medical history.
Think about what you want to achieve through treatment.

instructions.title: Engage in the Consultation
details: Be open and honest about your thoughts, feelings, and experiences.
Ask questions about potential diagnoses, treatment options (therapy, medication), and what to expect.
Work with the psychiatrist to create a treatment plan that feels right for you.

instructions.title: Follow Up on Your Treatment Plan
details: Attend follow-up appointments as scheduled.
Take any prescribed medication consistently and exactly as directed.
Communicate any side effects or concerns to your doctor immediately. Do not stop medication without consulting them.
